description.narrative: The project's main focus is assisting the country in the preparation and submission of its Second Biennial Update Report on Climate Change to the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: Second Biennial Update Report (SBUR) document prepared and submitted

comment.narrative: The First Biennial Update Report (FBUR) endorsed by the Government and submitted to the UNFCCC (26 Feb 2015). The FBUR contains relevant data for the country up to 2014.

The Second Biennial Update Report has been completed in accordance with the guidelines for the preparation of BURs from non-Annex I parties to the UNFCCC, as adopted at COP 17 (Decision 2/CP.17 and Annex III). It also incorporates feedback received during a 2015 Technical Analysis of the First Biennial Update Report (FBUR). The SBUR makes a step forward towards setting a transparency framework for reporting emissions, advancing the previous climate change reports to UNFCCC. It gives a snapshot of GHG emissions in the country and an overview of what the country is doing and should do to address the climate change. More specifically, the SBUR provides: updated National Inventory of GHG emissions and nationally adopted emission factors up to 2014; the baseline and mitigation scenarios by 2035 for non-energy sectors validated to ensure alignment with relevant national priorities; co- benefit analyses of the proposed actions in various mitigation scenarios and impact analyses of different policy instruments for GHG emission reduction; technology, financial and capacity gaps and needs for implementation of mitigation actions and recommendation for addressing the needs; and detailed analyses of the capacities (human and financial) to implement each of the steps for operationalization of the domestic Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) system. The SBUR is expected to be adopted by the Government in the first quarter of 2018. Because the SBUR contains very formal, technical language, a lot of efforts have been invested in producing visual tools that translate the SBUR from “UN-ese” into plain language understandable for the broader public (www.klimatskipromeni.mk ). Also, the primary information portal for climate change information i.e. the national climate change website (www.klimatskipromeni.mk) has been redesigned as a “one-stop shop.” In addition to all national policies and reports on climate change, the website has several interactive features, including two interactive features—one for policy-makers and one for the public—that compare different mitigation measures. Two impact analyses of different policy instruments for GHG emission reduction in final phase of development (one for household heating, the other for transport sector). Two topics related to the preparation of the National Communications and Biennial Update reports have been identified as best practices and widely promoted: one on the Quality Assurance/Quality Control and Verification in the National GHG Inventory for the SBUR (http://www.un-gsp.org/best-practices/documents ), and the other on open data and participatory policymaking for climate action http://klimatskipromeni.mk/?LCID=162&NewsID=550 ). The first one was promoted on a side event at the CoP in Bon, and the second one shall be also promoted at the Open Government Partnership conference in Buenos Aires. The CO was a host of a sub-regional conference aimed at bringing together the Climate and Gender Focal Points from the Ministries and Institutions in Western Balkan countries to discuss the opportunities and the challenges to mainstream gender into the development process of National Communications and Biennial Update Reports to the UNFCCC. At this meeting countries identified key elements of a gender roadmap/climate action plan, which will provide concrete steps - and identify responsibilities - aimed at integrating gender considerations into the next NC/BUR by applying the “Gender Responsive National Communications Toolkit” developed by the UNDP/UNEP Global Support Program for National Communications and Biennial Update Reports.

The Second Biennial Update Report has been completed in accordance with the guidelines for the preparation of BURs from non-Annex I parties to the UNFCCC, as adopted at COP 17 (Decision 2/CP.17 and Annex III). It also incorporates feedback received during a 2015 Technical Analysis of the First Biennial Update Report (FBUR). The SBUR makes a step forward towards setting a transparency framework for reporting emissions, advancing the previous climate change reports to UNFCCC. It gives a snapshot of GHG emissions in the country and an overview of what the country is doing and should do to address the climate change. More specifically, the SBUR provides: updated National Inventory of GHG emissions and nationally adopted emission factors up to 2014; the baseline and mitigation scenarios by 2035 for non-energy sectors validated to ensure alignment with relevant national priorities; co- benefit analyses of the proposed actions in various mitigation scenarios and impact analyses of different policy instruments for GHG emission reduction; technology, financial and capacity gaps and needs for implementation of mitigation actions and recommendation for addressing the needs; and detailed analyses of the capacities (human and financial) to implement each of the steps for operationalization of the domestic Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) system. The SBUR is expected to be adopted by the Government in the first quarter of 2018. Because the SBUR contains very formal, technical language, a lot of efforts have been invested in producing visual tools that translate the SBUR from “UN-ese” into plain language understandable for the broader public (www.klimatskipromeni.mk ). Also, the primary information portal for climate change information i.e. the national climate change website (www.klimatskipromeni.mk) has been redesigned as a “one-stop shop.” In addition to all national policies and reports on climate change, the website has several interactive features, including two interactive features—one for policy-makers and one for the public—that compare different mitigation measures. Two impact analyses of different policy instruments for GHG emission reduction in final phase of development (one for household heating, the other for transport sector). Two topics related to the preparation of the National Communications and Biennial Update reports have been identified as best practices and widely promoted: one on the Quality Assurance/Quality Control and Verification in the National GHG Inventory for the SBUR (http://www.un-gsp.org/best-practices/documents ), and the other on open data and participatory policymaking for climate action http://klimatskipromeni.mk/?LCID=162&NewsID=550 ). The first one was promoted on a side event at the CoP in Bon, and the second one shall be also promoted at the Open Government Partnership conference in Buenos Aires. The CO was a host of a sub-regional conference aimed at bringing together the Climate and Gender Focal Points from the Ministries and Institutions in Western Balkan countries to discuss the opportunities and the challenges to mainstream gender into the development process of National Communications and Biennial Update Reports to the UNFCCC. At this meeting countries identified key elements of a gender roadmap/climate action plan, which will provide concrete steps - and identify responsibilities - aimed at integrating gender considerations into the next NC/BUR by applying the “Gender Responsive National Communications Toolkit” developed by the UNDP/UNEP Global Support Program for National Communications and Biennial Update Reports.
- Second Biennial Update Report adopted by the Government and submitted to the UNFCCC - COPERT database (transport data) finalised - Gender and Climate Change Roadmap developed

The Second Biennial Update Report on Climate Change (SBUR) adopted by the Government and officially submitted to UNFCCC on Mach 5th 2018, thus fulfilling the country's obligations to the Convention under Dec. 1/CP. 16 par. 60 and Dec 2/CP. 17 par. 41 and it’s Annex III. The SBUR and additional visualizations materials printed , widely promoted and distributed to all relevant stakeholders. The data of the national vehicle fleet data used to develop COPERT vehicle database, enabling Tier 3 reporting for the road transport sector for both greenhouse gas and air quality inventories in the country. The impact analyses of different policy instruments for GHG emission reduction in road transport sector finalized as per real data input for City of Skopje and recommendations for mitigation actions provided. A Gender and Climate Change Roadmap has been developed, enabling integration of gender aspect in the subsequent Biennial Update Reports and National Communications on Climate Change.
- Second Biennial Update Report adopted by the Government and submitted to the UNFCCC - COPERT database (transport data) finalised - Gender and Climate Change Roadmap developed

The Second Biennial Update Report on Climate Change (SBUR) adopted by the Government and officially submitted to UNFCCC on Mach 5th 2018, thus fulfilling the country's obligations to the Convention under Dec. 1/CP. 16 par. 60 and Dec 2/CP. 17 par. 41 and it’s Annex III. The SBUR and additional visualizations materials printed , widely promoted and distributed to all relevant stakeholders. The data of the national vehicle fleet data used to develop COPERT vehicle database, enabling Tier 3 reporting for the road transport sector for both greenhouse gas and air quality inventories in the country. The impact analyses of different policy instruments for GHG emission reduction in road transport sector finalized as per real data input for City of Skopje and recommendations for mitigation actions provided. A Gender and Climate Change Roadmap has been developed, enabling integration of gender aspect in the subsequent Biennial Update Reports and National Communications on Climate Change.

The process for the development of the of the Second Biennial Update Report preparation have been started by bringing on board the members of various team and the establishment of the participatory mechanism that will ensure that views and opinions of all relevant stakeholders are offered and taken into consideration. The information on the GHG inventories for the period 1990-2012 has been updated, and the new Inventory for the period 2013-2014 have been developed.

The process for the development of the of the Second Biennial Update Report preparation have been started by bringing on board the members of various team and the establishment of the participatory mechanism that will ensure that views and opinions of all relevant stakeholders are offered and taken into consideration. The information on the GHG inventories for the period 1990-2012 has been updated, and the new Inventory for the period 2013-2014 have been developed.
